column1: This week is International Education Week. We’re celebrating with a photo contest that features moments of experiences captured by Hawkeyes who studied abroad::: international students on campus::: staff::: and alumni. Click through to see a few of the favorites. https://bit.ly/3D8BSCT

column4: I never had a chance to study abroad::: but there were always plenty of opportunities to interact with students from other countries on campus. I remember being a conversational partner with students from Ivory Coast and Sri Lanka. Also::: many associations of students from certain countries and regions had periodic festivals. I remember celebrating Diwali with a grad school classmate from Mumbai and her compatriots from various parts of India. We also celebrated festivals with students from west Africa. I remember Old Brick being a venue for these events::: and Iowa had a vibrant international center in the early to mid 1980s when I studied there.

column1: Hancher is approaching is 50th anniversary. You don't have to look to see how the "the largest classroom on campus" has had an impact on Iowa. https://bit.ly/3EQAbv2
column3: I worked as an usher and then an aisle captain at old Hancher while I was in grad school. As a result::: I was fortunate to see many “big name” productions::: as well as several minor ones.
column4: Graduated at a wonderful celebration in December 1977. The highlight was receiving my diploma from President Willard (Sandy) Boyd. A very memorable day in my life.
column5: While they were building the new Hancher the University held many smaller concerts in the old Thomas More Church west of Hancher on the other side of Riverside Drive. Many nights during intermission I would go out on the balcony of the church and look over the trees at the progress of the new building. It was subtly uplifting to see it coming through some years when many buildings had been damaged in the flood of 2008. It is a fine improvement over its predecessor.
column6: I performed there during All State Music Camp back in the 70s. (Actually at the Union before the old Hancher was completed.) Then as a student I was an usher from 1977-1979. A most enjoyable time of my life.
column7: Awesome photos of a great college campus at the University of Iowa. Part of the campus .

column1: When Hayden Fry came to Iowa in 1979 to instill a sense of solidarity among his players::: he introduced "the swarm." Instead of simply jogging onto the field before games::: Fry had his players lock hands::: with the captains leading the way out of the tunnel.
column3:
I wanted the players to feel like they were part of a family::: to be conscious of that controlled togetherness as they made that slow entrance onto the field. It had a great psychological effect on the opposing team::: too. They'd never seen anything like it.

Hayden Fry
column4: The Swarm is awesome. Got to see it in Tucson and Tempe in AZ. The only game I got to see Hayden Fry coach live. Go Hawks!
column5: It's an amazing sight to watch all of those young men "swarm" out of the tunnel on game day. Go::: Hawks!
column6: Hayden was a Psychology major. He changed the uniforms to look like the Steelers . More importantly he had the visiting locker room painted pink!
column7: Coach Fry was a creative thinker and understood how important culture was. He gave Iowa the Tiger Hawk::: updated uniforms::: the swarm::: a pink locker room for visitors and so much more. He was great coach and brilliant leader.
column8: I'll never forget seeing the first swarm! Hayden Fry's first game at Iowa was also my first game! Thanks::: Coach! Go Hawks!
column9: Hayden Fry brought so much more to the Iowa football program!! And Hawkeye Nation has never looked back! Go Hawks!
column10: I remember this like it was yesterday! He also redesigned the uniforms to mimic the Steelers. The goal posts started coming down as well. Fond memories

column1: 50 years ago::: two University of Iowa students set out on an amateur cave diving trip::: and returned having discovered Coldwater Cave::: the largest and longest cave in the upper Midwest. https://bit.ly/3ibbVtB
column3: I was so glad to see this article. I meant Dave and was honored to be with them when they installed the gate at the entrance to the cave.
column4: Real life example of having nerves of steel::: exploring uncharted underwater caves 50 years back - respect!
column5: I also got to climb down the ladder into this cave when I was a geology student. It was quite the experience!
column6: Wow::: great article and IPTV video! I grew up in NE Iowa and never knew this cave existed!
column7: Between the trips we took for Intro to Geology with Dr. Baker and the Iowa Mountaineers trips::: stories like this bring back great memories of my undergrad days in the early 80s!
column8: One time my grandad swore he went into cold water cave. He said it was like walking into a New York ulsubway tunnel without the train cars. I said granddaddy you were once arrested for trespassing in the NY subway back in ‘78 you’ve never been in a cave. He says ‘sonny you’re right::: but one can spelunk in ones dreams as Kierkegaard would say.”
column9: Steve knew these guys while at Iowa. When I worked for Governor Bob Ray for Natural Resources::: I got the State Geologist to take us down the drilled 30” shaft to enter the cave. We spent 5 hours down there enjoying the sights. 🎉👍🏽❤️
column10: I have ALWAYS wanted to be able to go down into the cave. Sigh...
column11: I will be making my second trip into the cave next weekend. Very excited.
column12: As a UI Geology Graduate (MS1991) I had the opportunity to visit Coldwater Cave in February 1991 with one of my fellow UI Geology graduate students. An impressive place to experience

column1: A common side effect of cancer is "chemo brain" - the term for a mental fog associated with the treatment that can cause difficulties in thinking::: focus::: and memory. column1: University of Iowa Hospitals & Clinics reached a major milestone recently::: completing its 10:::000th in-vitro fertilization (IVF) procedure::: bringing immeasurable joy to many families: http://spr.ly/6011yQZkb
column3: Thank you for my beautiful daughter! Photo by Sarah Siler Photography
column4: Thanks to UIHC and their IVF and donor embryo program!! ❤️ We have a boy and a girl who started kindergarten and preschool this year!
column5: My 24 year old daughter and 21 year old twin sons are a part of that 10:::000. So very grateful. My life’s greatest blessings. ❤️
column6: It was an honor & privilege to have been a part of this IVF team for 30 years from 1990 to October 2020. Cheers & continued support to the current team in working with patients in their quest to become parents. CONGRATULATIONS
column7: I was an employee there and so happy for all the families who benefit from this procedure. Craig and Brad::: thank you! And all the nurses who make it possible!
column8: So grateful to this amazing staff::: many of whom we now count as friends::: for the blessing of our 3 children::: our twins now UI graduates. I know the joy these many other parents feel. The UI Center for Advanced Reproductive Care has reached an amazing milestone!
column9: My 2 youngest grandbabies are part of those 10:::000 UIHC IVF babies. Without that we would not have them::: so thankful that UIHC offers this technology!! So cool to know that they are part of this milestone.
column10:

column12: I'm thankful for our two IVF kiddos. Thank you for all you do!

column1: “The Father of Space Science” James Van Allen led Iowa in earning recognition as a world leader in space research. Click through the photos to learn more about the scientist whose impact on space and at Iowa is still felt today. https://bit.ly/3k4i1fu
column3: I taught at “The new school” in Mt. Pleasant IA. A naming contest was held::: and it was named Van Allen elementary school in his honor.
column4: I had the pleasure of meeting him while in school! We were playing frisbee in the physics building late at night - and apparently disturbed him. He invited us into his office and showed us around - all kinds of developmental space hardware. I had also seen him speak at Tau Beta Pi functions (eng honors organization). He was a cool guy
column5: I took his class at Iowa::: he was a wonderful teacher and a very humble person. He and his wife would eat Sunday dinners in the school cafeteria with students. He would always put a joke up at the end of his lectures. I really liked him::: he was so smart and yet so humble.
column6: I took an Intro to Astronomy class which was his only undergraduate class that he taught. Three times each week he lectured. He discussed how he was working on Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 and what information he wanted to collect on those missions. He was a brilliant individual.
column7: In 1975::: when I started grad school::: Professor Van Allen was in the airport limo I took from the Cedar Rapids Airport to Iowa City. It was a great start to my time at Iowa.
column8: I never officially met him but he taught a class in the same room just before my class. He was always staying after answering any questions students had.
column9: I met him and his family - all friendly and down to earth::: even though he and the Van Allen Belt were big news::: when I was an undergraduate.
column10: It was an absolute pleasure working at The Department of Physics and Astronomy. Dr. VanAllen is so down to earth in spite of his great fame.
column11: I met him occasionally when picking up my future(now ex) wife Barb. She had a work study job in his office our junior year
column12: I “met” Dr. Van Allen by chance in about 1992 in the Eagles grocery store on I believe it was North Dodge. We were both looking at crackers. Of course::: there were a multitude of them in front of us and we were both sort of perplexed in our indecision. He greeted me kindly and said “We clearly have too many choices.“ And then he laughed. I don’t think he had any idea that I knew who he was. I was kind of awestruck.
column13: They named our grade school after him in the year 1964 when it was built ::::::::::::and I guess his name is not offensive because they have never changed the name after all these years ::::::
column14: Yes::: and also visit the building at ISU which shows the invention of the computer!
column15: He was from my home town and one of our elementary schools is named after him!!!!
column16: The " Van Allen" Belt bears his name. I was High School Scholar in Iowa when this happening!!!
column17: I’ve heard he was a very humble man! ❤️
column18: I still say every time a rocket goes up::: momentarily breaking the radiation belt::: we get crazy weather.

column20: I remember one time my grandad told me about how he was walking past this building in Iowa city in the 1950s and this guy comes running out and yells “I need help! I am about to finish my work on charged particles surrounding the earth::: but I can’t figure out what shape they are as my trousers keep falling down!” Now my grandad was a salt of the earth Iowan who 9 times out of 10 wore suspenders::: but on that fateful day he was wearing an old leather belt he got while visiting his folks in South Dakota (a story for another time!) and he looked back at the man::: who was holding up his slacks while trying to open the door. My grandad ran over and said “it’s alright there you ol rascal::: you can have my belt.” The man exclaimed::: “Belt? Did you say belt? Eureka! They are radiation belts! Of course!” And by golly that man ran off right out of his pants leaving them on the sidewalk. Now my grandad was born in a sod house and never threw away good pants. well he picked them up and wore those trousers until they went out of fashion with the bell bottom fad. The way he told the story it led me to believe he met Van Allen himself::: but we may never know. Grandad was buried in those pants though
column21: Hubby had a class of his but alas I was not a real science guy::: just political 😉. FYI if I had a do-over::: I’d be a Geologist 👍🏽😎 🪨

column29:
I will never forget how Dr Van Allen helped spark my lifelong enthusiasm for science and stoked my curiosity that has served me Very well through my entire life.

In 8th grade::: in my small school::: we had a year long large (for me at the time a seemingly insurmountable mountain) project. I was struggling with sources for my subject - NASA. Our library was inadequate for this and this was Loooong before the internet.

So being the direct man he was::: my father rang the university and happened to get to talk to "someone". Dad explained my consternation and asked for help.

Not more than a week later BOXES began showing up. Dozens of scientific journals::: publications::: picture of the Viking missions. More than I could have used in 2 years :)

I asked who exactly had my father talked to - van somebody?!? I looked at the return label and was dumbfounded when the return addresses were all James Van Allen.

It never hurts to ask for help- you never know when you may get the help of legends :)
column30: I took physics and astronomy from Dr. James Van Allen. He taught entry level classes to spark interest
column31: My roommate took his course in astronomy.
column32: Took Astronomy 101 from Dr. Van Allen my freshman year. He was amazing!😀
column33:
What a brilliant::: nice::: humble man!
I was in charge of the 1980 annual meeting of the International Microwave Power Institute. The meeting was always held in the home city of the president of the organization. In 1978::: it was in Monaco; in 1979 in Ottawa CN; in 1980 in Iowa City::: IA!!! One of the highlights of the meeting was an after-dinner speech by Dr. Van Allen. He spoke for about 45 minutes::: using slides and no notes. Then::: he graciously took questions from the audience. People were absolutely enthralled.... and stayed until close to 10 p.m. He wouldn't accept any compensation::: and told us what a wonderful evening he'd had!

column37:
This is completely unacceptable.

As a University of Iowa Alum::: both undergraduate and graduate::: and an Iowa City native::: this is so very disappointing.

I live in Coralville with my family. I've been in that tower during a 2019 football game when my youngest was hospitalized. He was later hospitalized 4 more times in 2020 - twice on oxygen.

While I'm sure the fireworks were very cool to watch::: I can't imagine some of those kids and their parents up there appreciated the tone-deaf message this is sending. Tanya Price? Would you appreciate being waved to by a crowd of maskless kids during a pandemic while your immunocompromis
ed kiddo is in the hospital?

Now that the students are back and school is also starting::: we will begin - already started - to see levels of cases and hospitalization
s in the pediatric population that we didn't see before. Katy Kennedy::: am I overreacting here?

I'm disappointed in the University of Iowa. If the wave is truly #FTK.... Then act like it.

column48:
James Halman II My kid is at Iowa (Stead Family Children's Hospital) over and over again. That's why I worry about it and that's why I think the concept of a group of hundreds of maskless students participating in the wave goes against everything the wave itself stands for. To be clear::: I'm talking about the wave::: nothing else.

I can never be able to put into words how helpless it feels as a parent to watch your child have to fight so hard to do something as simple as breathe (not to mention worrying about other underlying concerns to complicate matters).

I also know how much The Wave means to children and families at the hospital. For many families in that hospital::: the days are long and we often felt invisible - like we were stuck in this horrible situation but the rest of the world just went on outside that tower. The Wave lets families and children be seen::: acknowledged. To do The Wave at this event::: an event that increases the risk of Covid spreading in one of the communities patients at the children's hospital live in...it's beyond demoralizing and quite frankly a slap in the face to many::: many families in there.
column49: STOP! Please::: just STOP! Everyone has different opinions and if you want to talk COVID-19 or Mask wearing please go to the other site. Let’s just all agree we want our kids to be safe while having a great college experience.

column1:
Dear First-year Hawkeyes: If there’s anything we’ve learned over the last year and a half::: it’s that we don’t know what will happen next and it’s important to be grateful for what we have now.

As you move into your new home away from home and anticipate the next chapter of your lives::: take a moment to appreciate the emotions that your parents and family might be feeling.

While they’re recounting your biggest milestones and are so proud of you::: they’re also remembering the family movie nights::: morning greetings::: and supporting you at all your school events. They’re thinking about your empty chair at the dinner table and fearing how quiet it will be at home.

So::: when you move in tomorrow and your mom wants to unpack your clothes and make your bed::: let her. When your dad wants to introduce himself to all the people on your floor::: let him. When they want to take a million pictures::: keep smiling bright.

Take a moment to reflect on everything they’ve done to help get you to this moment. As you start this new chapter of your life::: remember they are also starting a new chapter of theirs. And when it’s time to say “goodbye:::” hug them a little longer and tighter.

Welcome to the Hawkeye family.

I took my son to see Field of Dreams. I fell in love with it. I cried. (even then). I wasn't much of a baseball fan nor is my son but I began to like the sport thanks to a nephew of mine who sadly died in January of this year of Cancer. He was a Detroit Tigers fan and so am I. But I LOVE the movie because it reminds me of the years my son and I lived in Iowa and it brings tears to my eyes all the time I watch the movie. Think I'll watch it tonight. Thank you Mr. Kinsella for writing the story and thank those who put it to action in a movie called "Field of Dreams."

column21: The inventor of Gatorade was doing research in this area before his death. What he discovered was certain foods were contributing to a child’s autism. They changed children’s diets and over a short period of time was able to document what foods were effective and those that were not. The younger the child that was on the diet::: the more rapid and notable the change.
column22:
Per Mayo Clinic.org::: autism is caused by a problem with brain development. It impacts how a person perceives and socializes with others causing problems in communication and social interaction. It begins in early childhood and continues::: eventually causing problems with function in society.

It is a physical problem with the brain::: and is a disability. It is not caused by learned behavior::: such as from parenting. It would be good to read up on it. Many well known people suffer from it::: including Bill Gates and Dan Akroyd.

column1: We're just weeks away from welcoming our newest Hawkeyes in the Class of 2025 to campus. What's one piece of advice you'd give to our newest Hawkeyes or to parents with a student leaving home for the first time?
column3: I started texting my daughter “Night Love You” every night the day she moved into her dorm. It is ten years later and we still do this everyday. You can never tell your kids you love them too much.
column4: To freshman parents from the parent of a class of 2012 civil engineering grad: Breathe. Set a time for an in-person call each week - make it your son/daughter’s responsibility to reach out. Be available but step back. You don’t need to know a lot of things that they are doing Trust that you did a great job as a parent. Let your freshman shine.
column5: Every day brings new people::: places & ideas.. put yourself out there and you will grow::: change::: & become independent. Welcome what’s ahead 😎🖤💛🌟🌀
column6: Work hard::: do your best always and absolutely celebrate every chance you get!🎉
column7: Make sure you hit the books and have a set time to study when you get home :::::::::Write down the time you start and end your studies and keep track of the hrs so you answer to yourself ::::::be careful of too much fun because you will flunk out ::::::its so much harder than high school :::::::::The 1st year flunks alot of students out :::::::::
column8: Keep doing your hobbies - they’re good for your mental health. There are amazing bands::: orchestras::: club sports and more to be involved with. You don’t have to be a music major or a scholarship athlete to do something you love!!
column9: Meet every new opportunity for adventure. At a large university like Iowa you'll have endless opportunities to try new things::: take as many of them as possible. Learning happens outside of the comfort zone-\-\and as much learning will happen outside of the classroom as it does in it.
column10: To both parents and students::: you are welcome to this amazing place. I do have something to say to the parents. Don't you ever get embarrassed and hold back your tears when you leave your children at the dorm. Is hard but it will be so worth it for both. You will miss them back at home but the thought of seeing them and hugging them the next time you get together::: will have a special meaning. Welcome Hawkeyes!! Be extraordinary 💛🖤💛🖤💛🖤
column11: As a parent you have to let your Hawk explore & be free. That was not easy for me. Have a plan of course because you do need to check on your kid::: but try not to smother. It’s their time::: so let them grow & become who you sent them there to be! You taught them the basics so trust that they got it! Also::: never sign anything without reading it! #OnIowa #GoHawks 🖤💛
column12: Move in day was always stressful and chaotic::: now that I look back on it. It was fun and one of most proudest days of your life as a parent. And by the way if you are in Hillcrest::: use the other elevator than no one knows about 😜Good luck Hawkeyes🖤💛
column13: One-way streets. Introduce yourself to them... And remember them! Other than that::: enjoy::: be safe::: and make a difference! 😍
column14:
Manage your time! If you get your homework and studying taken care of Sunday/Monday/
Tuesday/
Wednesday night::: you’ll be ready to go out and enjoy yourself on Thursday/
Friday/
Saturday. Do 45 minutes to an hour each night Sun-Wed::: and you won’t have to cram at all::: just a little extra time right before finals/major tests.

I had way too many friends struggle and drop out in the first two semesters because of not managing their time properly.
column15: Challenge yourself to step out of your comfort zone. High school is over::: you have a chance to be the person you want to be::: to have the identity you want that can set you up for the rest of your life. Join clubs::: try out different groups::: take classes that you think are interesting even if they’re not on your degree track. Experience and explore while enjoying the safety that college provides.
column16:
Parents—prepare
to make a Walmart run after you think you and they have thought of everything. Once you’re settling them in the room::: you’ll discover you need—something.
...And prepare to make a Walmart run (of course::: you’ll ALWAYS pay) every time you visit. AND....it’s ok to be both relieved and grieved at the nest-leaving.
column17: I remember moving in Currier Hall fall of 1998. So many fun memories and people. #letsgohawks
column18: Students::: your classes are only one area of learning. Do the work::: but allow yourself the wonderful opportunity to explore new and different topics as well the ability to make friends from so many different cultures.
column19: Get vaccinated and encourage all your family and friends to do the same. Designate study time and “fun” time. Be kind to everyone.
column20: You don’t have to be Greek to have friends. In fact i highly suggest waiting until sophomore year to rush because you change so much your first year
column21: My dad wrote me a note as I was the first child in our whole family to go to college... And hid it in my luggage.... I found it after I was by myself. I still have it. Knowing I had their support 5 hours away meant the world to me! And when I was feeling a little homesick... It happens and it's ok ... I read it and felt better most times 😄
column22:
Parents-First of all::: one of the easiest move ins ever. The kids were helpful. Second-Let your baby shine!! This is what you raised them to do. They will love it there. Third-Don’t miss parent weekend-some of our greatest memories were made that weekend.
Kids-One and only-call your parents!! Check in!!! They just need to know you’re alright. 💛🖤💛🖤💛🖤 Oh and let them help set up your room and make your bed! Moms love doing that kind of stuff. Ha
column23: Parents: Send care packages and enclose an encouraging note. Students: Get involved::: it is a good way to meet others.
column24: Get out there! Get involved in something… a club::: a study group::: a fraternity::: a sorority::: yoga/work out group. Even with the lockdown last year::: there were still plenty of people to connect with. Enjoy being a Hawkeye!
column25: Focus on studies but also have fun time. Meet as many people as you can. Have a GREAT time. Loved my Hawkeye years!
column26: From a 21-year university professor and Iowa alum (me) to new freshmen: Go to your classes - don't skip them!! And please::: ask your professors for help early on if you don't understand something. They are there for YOU and want to help you succeed. If you don't ask for help::: they assume you understand the material. Relax and take everything one step at a time. Lastly::: get involved in one non-academic activity such as band::: orchestra::: choir::: so forth. It's a great stress reliever. Best wishes and have a fantastic year!!!! GO HAWKS!! 🖤💛
column27: Work hard::: get involved on campus::: and call your mom every once in awhile!
column28: Enjoy this new life experience as it will be gone sooner than you think!!
column29:
I never had more than a suitcase::: pillow and blanket/
sheets. Oh and a desk lamp borrowed from my brother when he was at Iowa 10 years earlier. Do these kids really need all that crap?
column30: Try things that are unfamiliar. Don’t just room with someone from high school - interact with classmates from other parts of the state and other states and countries. Learn another language. Use your core courses or gen ed courses to see what truly interests you.
column31: Do whatever you to keep the lines of communication open between you and your child.
column32:
As an alumnus and resident of the Iowa City area::: please get the vaccine and be safe. I don't want my city to have to impose restrictions because of temporary residents irresponsibilit
y. Oh::: and go to Studio13 and TIP YOUR QUEENS.
column33:
Be compassionate. Be kind.

Have fun! Take advantage of your education learning opportunities. You are paying for this.
column34: Put in the time and effort to study make a plan and stick to it. Freshman year is hard with all the activities that distract you. Enjoy college life but put education first.
column35: My daughter will be an incoming Freshman. She's vaccinated and wears masks.
column36: wash your hands!! It's no party when norovirus hits the dorms.
column37: Study hard and try not to party too hard! Go Hawks!!
column38: Girls never go out alone. Let each other know where your at. Put on phone tracking.
column39: Study hard but don’t forget to have fun too. And by all means whatever you think is important on fall Saturday’s it is not as important as the football game
column40: Yes::: the once a week phone call! A super phone to use for everything is a nice gift::: plus something to remind them of home::: like a plant!

column42: Leave your door open! You never know who you’ll meet on your floor. I met my best friends on mine.
column43: Have faith and trust in your ability to Achieve anything you are willing to put time into ::: don't expect ::: earn ! ::: and parents chill out lol jk..
column44: Vaccinate! Wear a mask! Be safe::: not sorry!
column45: Buy them lots of gift cards for living. Be able to deposit money into their account. Have them sign the graduate in 4 years contract with their respective school. For example Engineering.
column47: Remember that everyone in your freshman dorm is nervous also. Explore early and make friends 😊 Go Hawkeyes 👏👏
column48: Everything will be just fine::: give life time to settle down. Get involved and learn about the world around you.
column49:
Students: find a favorite study spot on campus and get to know your best study hours when it's available; the law library has gloriously large tables where you can spread out of needed. 2nd::: invest in fleece face coverings for those cold February walks across the river to get to a distant class.
Parents: provide your kids with enough space to sort through some answers on their own; pushing to stay too involved too often actually signals you don't trust them or your parenting of them. 2nd::: a thoughtful care package from home covers over a ton of homesickness!👍🏻

These unsung heroes showed up to their job every day risking everything dear to them in a deadly pandemic::: just to keep going. Yes::: their young children were left home alone and yes::: they risked unknowingly carried home the deadly infection to their high risk family members. And yes::: most of the researchers did this without much ado from others. Because those are the unsung heroes of human history. So if anyone is still reading the boring post::: please pause and say a silent “thank you” to the brave humans.

column10: This good but we can do better. The University of Iowa must be among the top 50 world wide and not among the top 150 only. To compete at the international level you need leadership with international experience. The trend of choosing similar leadership throughout the years is not enough and will not take us beyond where we are. You need more diversity and more leadership who has experience in higher education at the international level. The search committees for the Leadership head hunting need major shift away from the traditional choices and the limited pools to choose from. I have received three degrees from this university which I care about but major strategic decisions are needed. Look at Harvard::: Stanford ::: MIT::: UC Berkeley and copy their models.

column1:
To the class of 2021:

You were special from the moment you arrived.
In your first few weeks::: the wave was ushered in after the first quarter.
You rushed the field at Kinnick Stadium after decimating Ohio State.
You helped raise a record $3:::011:::015.24 For The Kids at Dance Marathon in 2018.
You lived the Hawkeye life to its fullest.
You improved yourself.
You served others.
AND You boldly persevered through a global pandemic.
There is no one like you.
You inspire us.
Go out and conquer the world.
And remember::: no matter where you go or what you do…
You’re always a Hawkeye!

column1: Bus 142 gained international fame 25 years ago with the publication of Jon Krakauer’s book Into the Wild::: which told the story of Christopher McCandless::: who came to Alaska to live off the land alone and stayed in the bus until his death in 1992. Now::: University of Iowa alumna Angela Linn::: a museum professional for more than 26 years::: is developing a plan to conserve::: interpret::: and exhibit the bus made famous by the book. https://bit.ly/3pKGesj
column3: Thanks for sharing our work!
column4: The bus is a fascinating piece of modern history and it is in exceptional::: capable and thoughtful hands. Thank you to Angela Linn and the museum !
column5: Watch the movie about it. It's really a good biography about Chris McCandless and his ups and downs. Quite the story and well worth watching.
column6: I've never understood the allure of this story. I read the book. He went out completely naive and underprepared and sentenced himself to death in the process. Not sure what there is to celebrate/ glorify.

column1: Duke Slater was selected into the NFL Hall of Fame. He was recognized as Iowa’s first black First Team All-American in 1921. After earning a bachelor’s degree::: Slater played in the NFL for 10 years and also completed a law degree at Iowa. He had an extremely successful professional career and continued to break down barriers when he became the first black judge to serve on the Superior Court of Chicago in 1960. Slater Residence Hall bears his name::: though it is documented that like other black students::: he was not allowed to live in university housing and endured other forms of racism during his time at Iowa. https://magazine.foriowa.org/story.php?ed=true&storyid=1880
column3: How about naming the field at Kinnick Stadium::: Duke Slater Field! It would be awesome to play football on a field in his name.

column5: Can someone at the university please tell me when black applicants were finally admitted to Iowa equally as white students::: and what year they were allowed to live in on-campus housing? I would also be curious to know what year students who had asked to be randomly matched with another roommate were matched without consideration to the students’ race.

column1: The campus community said ‘farewell’ to Seashore Hall::: a longtime multipurpose building that served as the university’s first teaching hospital. https://bit.ly/3a1k13s
column3: A family with a great social science tradition. I did my PhD under Karen Seashore::: Carl Seashore’s great niece::: at the University of Minnesota. I now teach in the Carver College of Medicine. All things come around! 💛🖤
column4: The Ed/Psych library was in this building in the 60’s. My sister worked there and I took some psychology courses there too.
column5: Any other photos of Seashore through the years? It would be nice to view it's transformation online.
column6: Sadly::: it was time. I had one class in Seashore.
column7: I remember it as East Hall when I attended- worked at the Audio Visual Department 67-69
column8: I have always been so very proud to have my BSN from the U. of Iowa. Being a student there and then working there set me up beautifully for the rest of my life. The place was and is so beautifully organized and oriented toward serving the broad community. I loved the Hospital Patient Taxis that went all over Iowa. Not to mention the utter brilliance that comes out of there!!!
column9: I spent many hours in those hallowed halls::: attaining both my MA and PhD in Sociology under the tutelage of excellent professors!
column10: I fondly remember doing research in the Sociology Library in Seashore Hall one summer when I was in Iowa City as a visiting undergraduate (from Wartburg College).....
column11: Farewell indeed! As a TA I had an office at Seashore Hall that I shared for office hours.
column12: Fortunately the outstanding healthcare tradition endures.
column13: So many memories there. Sad to see it go. Historic preservation never was much of a priority in Iowa City.

column13: For those of you who think there is nothing wrong with taking a knee during the National Anthem...Well::: you all need to step back and look into a mirror and ask yourself what you have done for your country. I'd be willing to bet the answer for the vast majority of you is not much. For those of us who served in the Military::: especially during war time know what we did. We all took a oath to defend the United States and the flag that stands for it. Many died for that flag::: including a classmate that went in with me during Vietnam. Taking a knee during the Nation Anthem is in bad taste. So don't thank a veteran for their service and then take a knee. column1: Jay Holstein is one of the University of Iowa’s most sought-after professors. In his 50 years::: he has taught more than 60:::000 Hawkeyes. Learn about his Jay’s impact in and outside the classroom and share a memory below if you took one of his classes.
column3:
Quest for Human Destiny....ever
yone wanted in::: & for good reason. It changed people’s lives::: changed the way you think. He’s an amazing professor & amazing speaker. He is by far the best professor I ever had. 💙
column4: Attending his lectures was akin to experiencing a biblical rock 'n roll stand-up Zen comedy routine...he's a fascinating individual with an acerbic wit::: a finely-tuned professor possessing 'layers of meaning'::: and perhaps the University of Iowa's greatest academic treasure!
column5: Loved his class! Also remember he was always running around campus like he was 30 years younger. I was a biology major::: so this was a very different experience for me. I wish everyone could take his class.
column6: The thing I remember most was his kindness. Beyond the education.
column7: I ended up with a minor in Religious Studies by accident because of him. Wonderful teacher! I wish I could find my notes. Class of ‘00
column8: First heard him speak at initiation to Phi Eta Sigma 1991 and was beyond impressed! Loved Old Testament Survey and Judeo Christian::: by far the most captivating professor at Iowa and Wash U for grad school. Just told my niece who is a freshman at Iowa this year about him!!!
column9: I took Old Testament History in 1975. The upper right black and white photo is the Professor I remember. He was one of the most engaging and informative storytellers I have ever encountered in my life!
column10:
Kyle & Jack - I took Judeo-Christian
Tradition my Freshman year at Iowa in 85-86. I truly believe that class changed the course of my life for the better. Thank you Professor Holstein.
column11: I ended up with a Religious Studies Minor because I took almost all of the classes he offered during the late 90s early 2000s. He is so compelling! My husband and I still talk about his classes and are baffled when we talk to other Hawkeyes that never took one of his classes! (They totally missed out!)
column12: My favorite moments from Professor Holstein were in summer class. Some one opened a Pepsi on a particularly hot day. He commented that whoever it was should really bring one for everyone::: or at least the professor. The next day there was a cold Pepsi on the podium::: which he opened and drank with a satisfying :::"ahhh!" He had every class in the palm of his hand.
column13: Best professor at Iowa - bar none! Loved every one of his classes and got A’s in all - my notes were feverishly scribbled because I didn’t want to miss a word. There won’t be another like him.
column14: I was in his Quest class and I remember people standing in the back or sitting in the aisle who weren’t enrolled but wanted to hear his amazing lectures!!
column15: When I took Quest for Human Destiny with Professor Holstein in the mid 90's it was in a very large lecture hall on the Pentacrest. I felt so lucky to be able to enroll in his course since EVERY seat was filled and there were students sitting and standing in the aisles who had to be asked to leave because of fire code restrictions on capacity. I've carried and shared many of the concepts that I learned in his course with me throughout my life. What a gift!
column16: I was lucky enough to take his class back in 2006. He created some of the most thought provoking discussions amongst the class that I have ever been a part of. He probed people's beliefs and brought you to a place where you could empathize with other backgrounds. Truly a one of a kind professor!
column17: I took his quest for human destiny. I remember thinking a few classes into the semester “This guy has some of the answers I need to know.” As the semester went on::: I found that I didn’t get any answers::: only more questions. Then it hit me. I was not learning WHAT to think but instead learning how to question how I thought.
column18: I took Judeo Christian Tradition my freshman year - he is one of the best instructors I've ever had. Wish he could have been my TA::: too🤣 I would be interested in taking another class of his via distance ed::: if that could ever be an option.
column19: Quest For Human Destiny was a great class for many reasons::: but it was also my first experience with a streaker 😆 I just wish I could remember what Professor Holstein had to say about it at the time.
column20: I never took one of his classes but remember hearing how great they were when I was an undergrad in the early 2000s.
column21: By far the most dynamic professor I ever had. Judeo Christian Tradition::: Quest for Human Destiny::: Old Testament Survey. Couldn’t get enough of his classes! Feel blessed to have learned from him!
column22:
A fascinating albeit eccentric man. I was teaching a class next to his and his very loud voice made my room shake. I went next door and asked him if he could lower his volume a bit. He did. I think he is an extraterrestria
l. Here he is:

https://
www.youtube.com/
watch?v=NT_1Kw24
TQo
column23:
Omg I took several classes from Dr. Holstein 1988-91! He had such incredible insights and his delivery was unmatched! Pretty sure I never missed a class. I learned a ton and was so engaged. I remember that he explained one reference to God was “Ya-hoo-wah-hoo
.” I don’t remember the lesson::: just the reference. Outstanding professor! So fun to hear he continues to lead and teach!
column24: Took many of his classes::: and his daughter Sarah was in some of my science classes as well!
column25: 50 years as an educator is phenomenally impressive!!
column26: I was a video tech for one of his classes::: when he taught on the old ICN distance education system. He wasn’t a fan of that teaching environment::: but he was incredibly kind to me. (He was already a campus legend by that point::: so I was a bit worried.)
column27: I had his class the Holocaust. He was by far the most interesting professor and by far the best class. His classes were always full. Brings back great memories.
column28: I was in a Quest for Human Destiny lecture on the afternoon of 9/11/01. As the news of the morning was passing through campus::: I wasn’t sure we’d have class. We did and I’ll never forget it. He flawlessly lectured from a common theme of “I know nothing will be the same after this.” I’ve thought about it a lot over the years. As a college level instructor myself::: he is a true inspiration.
column29: favorite class at Iowa was his Quest For Human Destiny. great orator::: really captivating speaker that provided a good foundation for learning and different perspectives
column30: Loved all 3 classes I took from Professor Holstein::: especially Quest for Human Destiny in summer session.
column31: I took several classes and loved every one. I appreciated Hemingway novels before I heard his lectures::: but they remain my favorite because of his passionate lectures - the only books I still have from college are the version of “The Old Man and the Sea” and “Snow of Kilimanjaro” we read in his class.
column32: Professor Holstein’s Quest for Human Destiny class was my favorite class while I was at Iowa. He was entertaining and insightful::: and he changed the way that you viewed the world. I wish that he had a podcast or similar media outlet that would allow us to continue to hear his lessons beyond graduation.
column33: My sister::: who is 13 years older than I and attended Morningside College::: have an ongoing debate about who had the better professor for the Old Testament. I know I won that one hands down. His lectures were so energizing and informative. So captivating::: it was like going to story hour. 1979 BS::: 1983 MD.
column34: I took his class The Bible and the Holocaust::: it was truly an honor to have him as a teacher!
column35: I took one of Professor Holstein’s classes every semester I was at Iowa. By far the best::: most memorable and educational classes I took. ❤️
column36: Having taken his Quest for Human Destiny class::: I respect the man a great deal more now. He is truly remarkable in so many ways.
column37:
Professor Holstein's lectures were fascinating and thoroughly engrossing. I took his class on Judeo-Christian
Tradition and Quest for Human Destiny in the mid-80s. There was ALWAYS a waiting list to get into his classes.

I hope his lectures were recorded and it would be awesome if U of I would stream them online. I would listen to them all again.
column38:
I was just telling some coworkers about Professor Holstein and his Quest For Human Destiny class. Loved the class. Tried to take Judeo-Christian
Tradition but it was always full. BA1989
column39: I work in Health care but Quest for Human Destiny is the class I think about most often. Loved Professor Holstein and try to be just as passionate with my students.
column40: Old Testament Survey::: hardest class to get into! Also took Quest for Human Destiny. Jay Holstein instilled the desire to be a life long learner!!
column41: My favorite professor of all time. I still think about the lectures and the books. I was glued to my seat::: hanging on every word.
column42: Hands down my favorite professor and I still bring up things I learned in Quest for Human Destiny 33 years ago.
column43: Quest was one of my favorite courses and due to how they did rotation back in the early 80’s with your ssn::: I had to wait 3 semesters to take it. People would sit in the stairways that is how much we wanted to be there
column44:
I was a non-traditional
student in 1989 and took a religion course. I was in the front row of the auditorium as I always sat in the front of every class. ( Yeah::: I know::: typical non-trad.)A skinny guy walks onto the stage with white tennis shoes and gave a fabulous lecture. He was funny and energetic and I was so thankful for an instructor who loved his job. I have said through all of my undergrad and gradute school::: I have never learned so much as I did that semester from Dr. Holstein. I may even have the book yet!
column45: When I listened to his lectures as a freshman from the small town of Algona I realized I was in a different world now. He was simply incredible and I never forgot him
column46: 1985 “Religion and Society”. I loved every minute of that class. I wish I could hear his lectures again.
column47: There is nothing I could say about Holstein that hasn’t already been said a hundred times over::: but his classes truly reshaped my entire way of thinking. I also still laugh when I think of the time he told me he’d kick me out if I ever wore a Boston Celtics shirt to his class again. “Bill Russell RUINED my childhood! RUINED IT!”😂
column48: I took his Old Testament class my last semester at Iowa. I truly enjoyed his course. My mom and stepdad have also taken classes taught by Dr. Holstein.
column49:
Quest for Human Destiny and Old Testament Survey...standi
ng room only! Two of the best classes of my college career!
column50:
Great professor and a great human being. I had to leave school in March of my sophomore year when my mom was dying of cancer. He was so supportive and allowed me to finish the class via “correspondence
” since it was 1979 and online didn’t exist. His support meant a lot. Great person!
column51: He is outstanding. Took every course he offered::: never missed a class. My fondest memories of my education at Iowa.
column52: Listen::: everyone who went to Iowa May remember this or that::: but this guy stood out. His classes were terrific::: always loved hearing what was next
column53: How is it possible in an auditorium of ~300 .. it felt like he was talking directly to me!? I took bible and the holocaust and Quest for Human Destiny ... it’s made me a better and more thoughtful person. Thank you Jay Holstein.
column54:
He told me I'd live in a box one day.

Still enjoyed him as a professor.
column56: Loved his Old Testament class! I took it in 1974-75.
column57: Honored to be one of the 60k. His class on the Holocaust was heart wrenching and eye-opening.
column58: I remember he was an interesting speaker but sitting in a lecture hall with 400 other students and then having discussions with TAs leading meant that I literally don’t even remember what class I took from him 🤷🏻‍♀️
column59: Always good-he spoke at our commencement also '91 classic!

I am one of those 60:::000 students he taught. Loved his Judeo-Christian

column62: I had him for two classes. Dynamic lecturer who made his classes very interesting. He remains one of only two professors from my undergrad years that I remember by name.
column63: I took took quest for human destiny in 2006::: still one of the best classes!
column64: I can still remember sitting in Professor Holstein’s lectures as he made Ancient Greece and Rome feel so real. A truly gifted teacher and scholar.

Judeo-Christian
Tradition::: Fall 1983::: and Quest for Human Destiny::: Spring 1984. 😊❤️
column92:
Most dynamic professor I had at Iowa::: no one wanted the Judeo portion of Judeo-Christian
Tradition to end. A memory that sticks out and embodies his conversational lecturing style:

Prof: [lecturing::: *stops abruptly::: mid sentence*] Was there a fire downtown today?
Class: [collectively nods]
Prof: [continues lecturing::: *stops abruptly again*] Is the Pita Pit ok?
Class: [nods]
Prof: Good::: you ever had the cheesesteak there? First time I had it I thought I was back in Philly! [continues lecture]

Somehow it always felt like he was talking and bantering right to you even when lecturing to a packed auditorium in McBride Hall.
column93:
I tried every semester but could never get into Quest from 1984-1988...sti
ll not over it. Did get into Judeo/
Christian; never missed it and absolutely loved it and him::: but he gave me 1 of only 2 C’s I’ve ever gotten in my life...still not over it😂. Yet still my favorite class ever!
column94: I was never able to get either of those classes::: but wish I had
column97: “It don’t matter” I can still hear his lectures!!!! 💕
column98: Quest for Human Destiny. He was great.
column100: I took 2::: so good I never skipped 😜
column101: Wouldn’t it be pretty to think so.
column103: All these comments make me want to meet him.
column104: Konnor Scanlon did you have him ?
column105: Professor Holstein instructed one of the most informational and interesting courses I’ve ever taken and I learned so much from this great instructor. “The Bible & The Holocaust” was the course I took. Right when Covid hit::: he was extremely understanding and helped me make it through my final semester at Iowa successfully. I took his course as an elective and I hung on his every word during lectures! I thought I knew a bit of what I would learn based on assumptions and the little bit of history I’ve hung onto since high school::: and I was pleasantly surprised to find out how wrong I was! One of my favorites by far and just the amount of information he provided that I have retained is unreal. I have had lengthy discussions with my boyfriend where I have shared with him the things I’ve learned from Professor Holstein and his course::: and I know both of us have passed this knowledge along to others. He gave me a profound respect and understanding of these events in history that I never had before::: and I know I won’t forget!
column106: The Holocaust seminar was the most important class I took in all my years at Iowa. Reading so many books from survivors and hearing Jay Holstein’s lectures impacted my entire life. An amazing professor::: guiding us all to dig for the truth.
column107:
If I remember correctly::: I had three of Professor Holstein's classes ('Old Testament Survey:::' 'Judeo-Christia
n Tradition:::' and 'Quest for Human Destiny') when I was an undergrad at Iowa. Fantastic professor::: and a genuinely interesting person! He would often start class by saying something really "random" and humorous. Two things I remember: 1) One time when he had a cold::: he was complaining about the amount of phlegm in his throat and snot in his nose. He asked the class::: "So::: dear students::: what do you do with your phlegm and snot?" and 2) Another day he was talking about how he enjoyed running::: especially early in the a.m. through downtown Iowa City. He said::: "So::: this morning I went for my usual jaunt through downtown. At one point I stopped to look at my reflection in one of the store windows and I thought::: 'Damn::: I am one handsome devil! I know that an ordained rabbi shouldn't say things like that::: but really::: I am incredibly handsome and in fantastic shape!'" :-) In all of my years as a student and a teacher::: I don't think I've ever seen anyone::: anywhere::: keep the rapt and undivided attention of 500-750 undergrads::: especially early in the morning. Holstein was/is one of those true "rock star" professors::: and wait lists to get into his classes were longer than lines for Rolling Stones concert tickets. Jill Slipper Scholtz::: Kent Bress::: Christopher von Gries::: Geoff Newton::: Colleen Frost Fullenkamp::: Joe Fullenkamp::: Mark Fullenkamp::: Jill Garmoe::: Andy Hall. (Andy Hall::: I know that you went to Iowa only for law school::: but I thought you would find this interesting.)
column108: I loved Quest for Human Destiny! Possibly the best class I’ve ever taken. I still remember and think about it 25 years later. And Holstein::: I did end up taking Death of Ivan Illych to read on the beach.
column109:
Like so many others have stated::: Quest For Human Destiny was thought-provoki
ng and completely engaging. I loved every minute of that class. I believe I still have my notes packed away::: after 36 years! Congratulations
to Dr. Holstein for such an outstanding career.
column110: We have friends and acquaintances where I have lived the past 33 years (Green Bay) who are Jewish. They were impressed that I could carry on an interesting conversation regarding their faith. I give all the credit to Rabbi Holstein. However::: I think the most impacting lecture he gave in my view was when he discussed the St. Louis being turned around and sent back to Europe during Hitler’s reign of terror. This was a part of US history that was missed in my high school course::: and I appreciate that he gave us a more complete account of history.
column111: I took every class he taught! He was just amazing!
column112: I ❤️ Prof Holstein’s lectures. Have many memories if the books I read in his class

we are so thankful for this institution as we were blessed with our daughter melanie who was a rubella baby....she was born profoundly deaf but if you met her today you would not know it....hearing aids were not the answer when that profoundly affected....she
attended speech therapy from age 3yrs thru age12 yrs every morning 5 days a week....she is amazing and so wish you could appreciate her brave life growing up during a time when disabilities were not acknowledged...
in her 20s she worked for tom harkin in washington dc and worked on the american disability act and today she continues to give back as she is in the administrative dept of the iowa city goodwill.....sh

column1: Every year::: about 60:::000 Americans are diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease. University of Iowa engineers and neurologists have developed a highly efficient algorithm that can detect the disease. The algorithm uses data from electroencephalogram tests::: or EEGs. It can diagnose the disease in real time. https://bit.ly/3ksTkYV
column3: THIS needs to be read. Be informed about Parkinson's.
column4: Jonna Petrou Andrew Petrou Elizabeth Petrou Kristin Petrou
column5: Interesting
column6:
Thank you University of Iowa for featuring our research work. Our main success was to utilize Linear Predictive Coding (LPC)::: which is nowadays used for real-time speech processing and voice recognition (like google assistant::: alexa or siri). This is how the article achieved diagnosis in real-time. Turns out LPC can be used very efficiently for Parkinson's disease (PD) diagnosis which is a major breakthrough in the field which can be used for real time PD treatment like deep brain stimulation. If you are interested::: please check out our other article on this: https://
www.frontiersin.
org/articles/
10.3389/
fnins.2020.00394
/full
column7: Fahim Anjum
column8: Such a devastating disease! My brother lived with this disease for 14 years! Although there is no cure::: yet::: that I know of::: early detection is very important.
column10: Very interesting::: thanks for the article.
column11: Christina Denney Miller
column12:
Are there effective treatments for Parkinson's disease that slow its progression in the earlier stages?
Otherwise::: I don't really see the positive side of knowing that you will get this disease (before you have symptoms) without there being a treatment or cure available.

I only say this because my Dad had ALS and getting that diagnosis earlier would not have helped anything. Hope is what helps you move forward and there was/and unfortunately still is no hope for someone with ALS...In cases like that::: "ignorance is bliss".

On the other hand::: I do hope this leads the researchers down the path to a cure! Good work::: Hawkeyes!
column17: Karla Mark Flannagan::: Sue Weber::: Heather Hammer::: Jill Hanna Weber with the history of Parkinson's disease in our family I find this really interesting.

“If this was something that parents were doing most of the time::: then that would be great:::” Plumert says. “But our study shows that parents aren’t using effective strategies to help their child learn about safe road crossings all that often. column10:
* Don't think it's late and try to serve your parents well anymore *

-Studying a lot and succeeding are not all achieved by yourself-

1. No matter how foolishly lacking parents::: they are certainly parents.

2. Parents living with disabilities are certainly parents.

3. Parents who haven't learned anything are definitely parents.

4. Parents who couldn't save money in their lifetime are certainly parents.

5. Usually very strict parents are rather very blessed parents.

6. Always discuss important things in life with your parents.

7. Synthesize almost everything in your daily life and inform your parents.

8. Understand and do what your parents usually say.

9. No matter how busy you are in your life::: call your parents frequently.

10. Go anywhere near you with your frustrated parents.

11. Pay your parents' pocket money like tithing. Everyone comes back.

12. Don't just neglect your poor-looking parents::: take care of them.

13. Do not disobey every single word of your parents::: but follow them well.

14. If you can't see your parents' eyes::: wear glasses and give them a hearing aid if your ears are dark.

15. My parents' health is my health. Check and take care of them from time to time.

16. Ask your parents about any difficulties while living.

17. Discuss well with each other so that there is no quarrel between siblings over parents.

18. The world with my parents seems to have passed::: but if I can't move::: there is no way.

19. If it is practically impossible to have parents::: seek help from the state.

20. If elderly parents are neglected::: they will be held liable for violation of their duty to support.

21. If you or your children marry and have children::: they are all parents.

22. When you become a parent::: then you can think of your parents properly.

23. If you take good care of your parents::: you will be helped by your children later.

24. When I was a child::: my parents' vice-versa were all things that my children told me to do well.

25. Make sure to see your parents as often as you had before.

The Gentle World of the East Lee In Seop.

column4: As a parent 8 hours away::: I am just wondering what is the University of Iowa doing to keep the kids safe? What is the university doing today to ensure that the Covid positive kids are truly OK::: physically? I thought when the university said they had dorms set aside for Covid positive students::: I thought they meant like a whole dorm building. Instead::: they have “isolation” rooms in a wing set aside in dorm buildings that house non-Covid positive students. My son has told me that all the Covid rooms in several dorms are already full. Believe me::: he knows first hand 😢. Also::: these kids are told to grab some clothes and hike across the campus with whatever they can take with them to a Covid isolation room. They are provided a bed::: dresser::: desk::: refrigerator and microwave but no tv. These kids have to stay in these rooms for approximately 10+ days without a tv. Of course they can’t carry their own tvs from across the campus. Then::: even though they may have an unlimited dining plan::: they are given their meals once per day and it is a very very limited menu::: with many items most kids wouldn’t eat. Housing and Dining does a wellness check every am. What about a member of the medical or nursing staff performing the wellness checks. What happens if they need help and can’t call?The school is isolating these kids::: they need to be checking on them quite a bit more than once per day and they should have access to calling in and having their food delivered to them....fresh::: hot food! My child said he got food delivered today but won’t get food delivered until Saturday. Is he not going to eat tomorrow? Honestly::: UI is not prepared for this pandemic and kids should not be on campus. Also::: what are mild symptoms vs moderate or severe? Is a 103 fever considered a mild symptom? These kids are kids and they need to be monitored and not just from a phone or someone dropping off their meals for the day! Not all of the positive kids were out partying. Covid is airborne!

column14: During the occupation of Japan at the end of WWII::: my father was a Lieutenant in the Marines and an Electrical Engineer. His occupation task was to rebuild the electrical grid of Yokosuka::: which had been almost entirely stripped of strategic metals. (almost all the copper wire had been pulled out for the war). He is 103 now::: and still a Marine.

HEMIPLEGIA: A condition caused by brain damage or spinal cord injury that leads to paralysis on one side of the body. It causes weakness::: problems with muscle control::: and muscle stiffness.

ADDICTION: The fact or condition of being addicted to a particular substance::: thing::: or activity.

DEMENTIA: A chronic or persistent disorder of the mental processes caused by brain disease or injury and marked by memory disorders::: personality changes::: and impaired reasoning.

CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE is the most common type of heart disease. It is caused by plaque buildup in the wall of the arteries that supply blood to the heart (called coronary arteries). Plaque is made up of cholesterol deposits. Plaque buildup causes the inside of the arteries to narrow over time. This process is called atherosclerosis
.

HYPOGONADISM: Reduction or absence of hormone secretion or other physiological activity of the gonads (testes or ovaries).

TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK: A brief episode of neurological dysfunction resulting from an interruption in the blood supply to the brain or the eye::: sometimes as a precursor of a stroke. Sometimes called a “mini-stroke:::“ a TIA causes stroke symptoms such as weakness::: vision or speech problems::: dizziness::: or headache. With a TIA::: however::: these effects usually last only a few minutes. It may not cause lasting brain damage::: but it often happens before a major stroke.

column1:
Today::: we commemorate Juneteenth::: the day that the last of the kidnapped and enslaved Black people and African people were freed in these United States.

Diversity at Iowa
June 19::: 2020 at 8:01 AM ·

Today::: we commemorate Juneteenth::: the day that the last of the kidnapped and enslaved Black people and African people were freed in these United States. Though physically emancipated::: our Black communities will never truly be free until Black bodies::: souls::: and minds in this country can wake up without the fear that their life will be ended too early::: without every day facing the trauma of a history that includes their enslavement::: and without having to live in a system that is built to work against them. Let us both remember this day and never forget that there is yet more work to do.
For more information on Juneteenth::: please go here: https://www.history.com/news/what-is-juneteenth?fbclid=IwAR2EqckEIM178tcsX9qGpfVU9666ThF-7fnl92nnrIT0qBsrimsX6U2Qcgk
Image of red::: black::: and green stripes and says “Juneteenth freedom day”

column5: Just would like everyone to know that slavery was still legal and practiced in Kentucky and Delaware until December 6th::: 1865. While juneteenth is used to celebrate the fact that no one is free until every one is free::: it was not the last day of slavery. One could argue that slavery still exists today in our prisons from labor exploitations to large corporations such as walmart.
